pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [f9548a83a6](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18102/commits/f9548a83a669a6647b9b15e4dfef46fea8454f00)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +10.46% | `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Unital` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Unital | 1501 | 1658 | +157 (+10.46%) |
| Mathlib.Topology.ContinuousMap.StarOrdered | 1595 | 1560 | -35 (-2.19%) |
| Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Rpow.Basic | 1797 | 1799 | +2 (+0.11%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.ContinuousMap.StarOrdered`|-35|
|<details><summary>18 files</summary> `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ApproximateUnit` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.CStarMatrix` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Basic` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Instances` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Integral` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Isometric` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.NonUnital` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Order` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Restrict` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Unique` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.Hom` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.Module.Constructions` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.Module.Defs` `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.SpecialFunctions.PosPart` `Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.StarOrder` `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.ExpLog` `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.PosPart` `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.HermitianFunctionalCalculus`</details>|1|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Rpow.Basic` `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Rpow.Isometric`|2|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Unitary`|69|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Unital`|157|
| `Mathlib.Topology.ContinuousMap.ContinuousSqrt` (new file)|1594|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ContinuousSqrt`
`+ instance (priority := 100) instContinuousSqrtRCLike {ùïú : Type*} [RCLike ùïú] :`
`+ instance : ContinuousSqrt ‚ÑÇ := instContinuousSqrtRCLike (ùïú := ‚ÑÇ)`
`+ instance : ContinuousSqrt ‚Ñù := instContinuousSqrtRCLike (ùïú := ‚Ñù)`
`+ instance : ContinuousSqrt ‚Ñù‚â•0`
`+ instance {R : Type*} [PartialOrder R] [NonUnitalSemiring R] [StarRing R]`
`- instance (priority := 100) instStarOrderedRingRCLike {ùïú : Type*} [RCLike ùïú] :`
`- starOrderedRing_of_sqrt`
`-- instStarOrderedRingComplex`
`-- instStarOrderedRingNNReal`
`-- instStarOrderedRingReal`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

About the increase in imports: `Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.NonUnital` had only the most bare-bones imports necessary to get it to work, but anyone who actually uses this file will likely have almost all the new imports pulled in already, so I don't think it's worth quibbling about (but I'm still happy to hear objections).

@eric-wieser I think you had asked about this a while ago. This is *not* the most general thing that could give you `StarOrderedRing C(Œ±, R)` (as that would be an additional data `pieces : ‚Ñï` and a function `sqrt : R √ó R ‚Üí Fin pieces ‚Üí R` which, given `x : R √ó R` with `x.1 ‚â§ x.2`, would satisfy `x.2 = x.1 + ‚àë n : Fin pieces, sqrt x n * sqrt x n`). But I don't think the more general thing is worth it, because I don't even know when it might hold (except maybe for `Œ±` discrete and `R := ‚Ñï` because of `Nat.sum_four_squares`).

> as that would be an additional data `pieces : ‚Ñï`

Just to check I understand the bigger picture here; is the reason this is needed that continuity somehow prevents us choosing a different number of pieces each time as we presumably can for pi types?

Edit: ah, maybe the problem is actually the finiteness and continuity is a distraction? #18209 worked fine for product types.

I think the answer is: it's both. I suspect that the proof you gave in #18209, while nice, obscures what's going on on "under the hood". If I have `(a, b)` and I express each of `a` and `b` as finite sums of `star s * s`, and there are different numbers in the terms, then the reason you can pad whichever one has fewer with `star 0 * 0` and then you're done. Likewise, this works for finite pi types, but *not* infinite ones due to the fact that you might decompose into arbitrarily many terms of the form `star s * s` as you go along the indices.

So, you might wonder if, supposing that every `r : R` decomposes into a finite sum of *at most* `n` terms of the form `star s * s` (with `n` independent of `r`), can you succeed for `C(Œ±, R)`? The issue here is that you need `n` *functions* `f` so that the sum of `star f * f` is your finite element. The problem is that for each `x : Œ±`, `f x` may decompose into a different number, and now the padding-by-zero trick doesn't work because you lose continuity (or maybe a better way to say it is that you have no good way to even *state* that this decomposition is continuous across `Œ±`).

Does this make sense?

(note: presumably it might be possible, although I'm not sure how, to cook up some example where you take two `StarOrderedRing`s `R‚ÇÅ` and `R‚ÇÇ`, where everything in `R‚ÇÅ` looks like `star s * s` and everything in `R‚ÇÇ` is the sum of two of these. Then you could maybe glue them together at zero. Then any continuous function with values in this space with domain `Œ±`, it would have to cross `0` to get from `R‚ÇÅ` to `R‚ÇÇ`, and then you could successfully switch pad with zero on the preimage of `R‚ÇÅ` and the result would be continuous.

I'm not sure the above description is actually possible given that these things need to be *rings*, and I don't even have an example of a `StarOrderedRing` like `R‚ÇÇ` right now, which is not itself an `R‚ÇÅ`.)

Thanks!

bors r+
:-1: Rejected by label
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13838162204/job/38718455143)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13838162204/job/38718454610)
I'm happy with this. @eric-wieser would you like to have a last look before we merge this?
I'm happy with this. @eric-wieser would you like to have a last look before we merge this?
This spelling avoiding subtraction feels a little strange to me; do we lose any interesting generality by using `OrderedSub` instead?

The issue is that it proliferates the type classes I would need to assume on the scalar ring for the continuous functional calculus, which would be annoying. (i.e., I would then need `[OrderedSub R] [ContinuousSub R] [ContinuousSqrt R]`)

Could you add a helper function that assumes `OrderedSub`, and use it to prove `ContinuousSqrt ‚Ñù‚â•0`? I know it doesn't make the proof shorter, but it leaves somewhere for you to put a comment explaining why actually defining things that way is annoying.
@eric-wieser I decided instead to simply add a bit to the module documentation explaining the situation and reasoning.
What diamond are you thinking of?

You can write an instance of this class for C*-algebras too, but the square root will go via the continuous functional calculus. But then `Complex` will have two non-propeq instances of this class. It's probably not a big deal because we essentially only care about this class to get the `StarOrderedRing` instance on the continuous functions, which is a `Prop`, and so there's virtually no reason to refer to this `sqrt` function.
If you want to enforce this, you could make `ContinuousSqrt : Prop`
I know, but that's a bit gross, and I don't think the existence of diamonds here is actually going to cause issues, but I'll add a warning.

```suggestion
by which we can ensure `C(Œ±, R)` has this property. This condition is satisfied
by `‚Ñù‚â•0`, `‚Ñù`, and `‚ÑÇ`, and the instances can be found in the file
```

```suggestion
Instead of asking for a well-behaved square root on `{x : R | 0 ‚â§ x}` in the obvious way, we instead require that, for every `x y  : R` such that `x ‚â§ y`, there exist some `s` such that `x + s*s = y`. This is because we need this type class to work for `‚Ñù‚â•0` for the
```
I think this is much clearer, I have no idea what a well-behaved square root on `{x : R √ó R | x.1 ‚â§ x.2}` means without scrolling down to the actual definition.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor: add a `ContinuousSqrt` class to conclude `StarOrderedRing C(Œ±, R)`
